meta.reference: TOEFL iBT Technical Manual RR-25-12; test designed for CEFR A1 to C2
meta.rules: First sentence intact. From second sentence every 2nd word: keep floor(length/2) chars, delete rest. 10 gaps per passage. 70-100 words per passage.

sets.A1: Beginner – simple present, high-frequency words, everyday topics
sets.A2: Elementary – simple past, basic connectors, familiar contexts
sets.B1: Intermediate – present perfect, modals, practical topics
sets.B2: Upper intermediate – general academic, varied syntax
sets.C1: Advanced – dense academic, nominalizations, complex collocations
sets.C2: Proficient – highly complex academic and abstract texts

A1.text: I like to eat fruit every day. Apples and bananas are my favourite snacks. I also drink water in the morning. My sister likes coffee but I prefer tea. We have breakfast at seven o'clock. Then we go to work or school. In the evening we watch television. Sometimes we read a book before sleep.

The cat sits on the sofa. It has black and white fur. Every day it drinks milk. The dog runs in the garden. They are good friends. Sometimes they play together. My family has two pets. We love them very much.
Today is Monday. I go to the office by bus. The bus stop is near my house. I leave home at eight. The journey takes thirty minutes. I start work at nine. I have lunch at one. I finish work at five.
My name is Anna. I live in a big city. There are many shops here. I like to buy clothes. My brother likes sports. He plays football every week. My mother works in a hospital. My father drives a car.

The weather is nice today. The sun is shining. There are no clouds in the sky. I want to go to the park. My friends will come with me. We will sit on the grass. We will talk and laugh. I am very happy.
This is my bedroom. There is a bed and a desk. I have a lamp on the desk. I read books at night. The window is big. I can see the street. My room is clean. I like it very much.
I get up at six. I wash my face. Then I eat breakfast. I wear a blue shirt. I take my bag and go. The school is not far. I walk for ten minutes. I arrive before eight.

She has a red bicycle. She rides it to the market. She buys bread and milk. She puts them in her bag. She goes home on foot. She cooks dinner at six. Her children help in the kitchen. They eat together at seven.
The book is on the table. It is a story about a dog. The dog is very clever. It can open doors. It helps the family. Everyone likes the dog. The story has a good end. I read it again and again.

We have a small garden. There are flowers and trees. My father waters the plants. My mother likes the roses. The roses are red and pink. In summer we sit outside. We drink cold juice. The garden is very beautiful.
He is a teacher. He works at a school. He teaches English and maths. The students like his lessons. He is kind and patient. He helps when they ask. The classroom is big. There are twenty desks.
The train is fast. It goes from London to Paris. The journey takes two hours. I sit by the window. I look at the fields. The countryside is green. I like long journeys. I read or sleep.

My grandmother lives in a village. Her house is old and small. She has a big garden. She grows vegetables there. She gives us tomatoes. We visit her every month. She tells us stories. We love her very much.
The phone is ringing. I run to answer it. It is my best friend. She wants to meet tomorrow. We will go to the cinema. We will watch a new film. I am excited. I say yes immediately.
Breakfast is important. I always eat something in the morning. I have cereal with milk. Sometimes I eat eggs. I drink orange juice. It gives me energy. I need energy for work. I never skip breakfast.

A2.text: Yesterday I went to the market. I bought some fresh vegetables. I met my neighbour there. She was carrying a heavy bag. I helped her to carry it. She thanked me and smiled. Then I walked back home. I cooked a simple dinner.

Last year we travelled to the mountains. The journey was long but beautiful. We stayed in a small hotel. The room had a nice view. We went hiking every morning. We took many photographs. The weather was perfect. We want to go again.

When I was young I lived in the country. There were no big buildings. We had a lot of space. I played in the fields. I had many friends. We rode our bicycles. Life was simple then. I have good memories.

My uncle sent me a letter. He wrote about his new job. He moved to another city. The job is in a bank. He likes his colleagues. He works from nine to five. He has a short lunch break. He will visit us in summer.
Last week I lost my keys. I looked everywhere in the house. I could not find them. I felt very worried. Then I remembered the car. The keys were in the car. I was so relieved. Now I keep a spare set.

The film was interesting. It told the story of a sailor. He sailed across the ocean. He met strange creatures. He found a secret island. The island had gold. He brought some home. Everyone was surprised.

She decided to learn English. She joined a language school. The classes were in the evening. She studied for two hours. She did her homework every day. Her teacher was very good. She made progress quickly. Now she can speak well.

We had a party last Saturday. Many friends came to the house. We put music on. We danced and sang. We ate pizza and cake. The children played games. Everyone had a good time. We cleaned up the next day.

The museum was closed on Monday. We went there on Tuesday instead. We saw old paintings. We saw sculptures too. The guide explained the history. We learned many new things. We spent three hours there. We were tired but happy.

He broke his arm last month. He went to the hospital. The doctor put it in a cast. He had to rest at home. He could not work for six weeks. He watched a lot of television. His arm is better now. He can drive again.
I received a present from my aunt. It was a blue sweater. I tried it on. It fitted perfectly. I wore it to school. My friends said it was nice. I wrote a thank-you note. I sent it the same day.

The meeting started at ten. We discussed the new project. Everyone gave their ideas. We wrote them on the board. We chose the best plan. The meeting ended at twelve. We agreed to meet again. I went back to my desk.

There was a storm at night. The wind was very strong. The rain beat on the windows. I could not sleep. I got up and read. In the morning the sun came out. I went to check the garden. Some flowers were damaged.

She applied for a new job. She had an interview last week. The manager asked many questions. She answered them carefully. She wore a smart suit. She felt nervous at first. Then she relaxed. They offered her the job.
We needed to fix the roof. We called a builder. He came the next day. He looked at the problem. He said it was not serious. He worked for two days. He used new materials. The roof is fine now.

B1.text: People have always wanted to travel. In the past only the rich could afford it. Today more people fly than ever before. Airlines offer cheap tickets. You can book online easily. You need a passport for international flights. You should arrive at the airport early. Security checks can take a long time.

Learning a language takes time. You cannot become fluent in a week. You need to practise every day. It helps to watch films. You can read books or newspapers. Many people use apps on their phones. You should not be afraid of mistakes. Everyone makes them when learning.

Healthy eating is important for everyone. You should eat plenty of fruit. Vegetables are good for your body. Try to avoid too much sugar. Drink water instead of soft drinks. Exercise is also very important. You do not need to go to a gym. Walking every day can be enough.

The internet has changed how we live. We can now shop from home. We can work from anywhere. We stay in touch with friends. We share photos and news. But we must be careful. Not everything online is true. We should protect our personal information.

Recycling helps the environment. Many towns have recycling centres. You can leave glass and paper there. Plastic bottles can also be recycled. It is important to sort your waste. Some materials take years to break down. We should all do our part. The planet will thank us later.

Good communication is a key skill. You need it at work. You need it at home. Listening is as important as speaking. You should look at the person. You should not interrupt. Ask questions if you do not understand. Clear communication avoids many problems.

Working from home has become common. Many companies now allow it. You need a quiet space. You need a good internet connection. It can be hard to switch off. Some people work too many hours. It is important to take breaks. You should have a clear routine.

Reading books has many benefits. It improves your vocabulary. It helps you to relax. It can take you to other worlds. Libraries are free to use. You can borrow many books. You can also use e-readers. There is something for everyone.

Saving money is a good habit. You should start when you are young. Put a little aside each month. You might need it later. You could use it for a holiday. You could use it for an emergency. Banks offer different types of accounts. It is worth comparing them.

Teamwork is important in most jobs. You need to get on with colleagues. You should share ideas openly. You must meet deadlines. Sometimes you will disagree. That is normal. You should talk about problems. Good teams solve problems together.

Stress can affect your health. Too much work can cause it. You may feel tired all the time. You may have trouble sleeping. It is important to find balance. Exercise can help to reduce stress. So can talking to friends. Do not be afraid to ask for help.

Public transport is useful in cities. Buses and trains run regularly. You can buy a day ticket. It is often cheaper than driving. You avoid traffic jams. You also help the environment. Many people use it to get to work. It is a good way to travel.

Making a budget is a smart idea. You write down your income. You write down your expenses. Then you see where the money goes. You can cut unnecessary spending. You can save for your goals. It takes discipline at first. Soon it becomes a habit.

Volunteering can be very rewarding. You give your time for free. You help people or causes. You learn new skills. You meet new people. Many organisations need volunteers. You can find opportunities online. Even a few hours can make a difference.

Time management is a useful skill. You make a list of tasks. You put them in order of priority. You focus on one thing at a time. You avoid distractions. You take short breaks. You feel more in control. You get more done.

B2.text: The Industrial Revolution began in Britain in the late eighteenth century. It marked a major shift from hand production to machines and new manufacturing processes. Factories replaced small workshops and cities grew rapidly as workers moved to find jobs. The invention of the steam engine was especially important because it powered trains and ships. Historians often argue that these changes laid the foundation for modern economic growth and urban life.
hints: Noun: 'shift' collocates with 'from X to Y'.
Plural noun after 'new'; process of making goods.
Past tense: events in the past.
Comparative form: cities became larger quickly.
Adjective: the engine was particularly significant.
Past tense; trains and ships were powered by steam.
Plural noun; people who study history.
Collocation: 'lay the foundation for' is fixed.

B2.text: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants use sunlight to make food. Green leaves contain a pigment called chlorophyll that captures light energy. The plant then combines this energy with water from the soil and carbon dioxide from the air. As a result the plant produces sugar and releases oxygen into the atmosphere. Without this process most life on Earth would not be able to survive.
hints: Subject-verb: the process that plants use.
Adjective; the colour of typical leaves.
Noun; gas that plants take in.

B2.text: The Roman Empire built thousands of miles of roads to connect its territories. These roads allowed soldiers and merchants to travel quickly between distant regions. Engineers designed the roads with a slight curve so that rainwater would drain to the sides. Many of these ancient roads are still visible today in parts of Europe. They remind us that good infrastructure has always been important for civilization.
hints: Plural noun; the empire constructed many.
Plural noun; people who buy and sell.
Plural noun; people who design and build.

B2.text: Climate change is affecting weather patterns around the world. Scientists have observed that average temperatures are rising and that extreme events such as droughts and floods are becoming more frequent. Governments and international organizations are working to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Individuals can also help by using less energy and supporting policies that protect the environment. Education and awareness are essential if we want to address this global challenge.
hints: Plural noun; bodies like the UN.

B2.text: The human brain contains roughly eighty-six billion neurons. These cells communicate with each other through electrical and chemical signals. When we learn something new the connections between certain neurons can become stronger. This process is often called neuroplasticity and it continues throughout our lives. Researchers are still discovering how the brain adapts to experience and injury.

Democracy allows citizens to participate in the political process by voting. In a representative democracy people elect officials to make decisions on their behalf. Freedom of speech and assembly are protected so that individuals can express their views. Critics argue that democracy is slow and that it sometimes fails to produce the best outcomes. Nevertheless many consider it the fairest system for governing diverse societies.
hints: Plural noun; members of a country.
Noun; the right to speak freely.

B2.text: The invention of the printing press in the fifteenth century changed how information was spread. Before that books had to be copied by hand which was slow and expensive. With the press many copies could be produced quickly and at lower cost. Ideas could then reach a wider audience and literacy rates began to rise. Historians often describe this as one of the most important developments in human history.
hints: Modal past: were able to be made.

B2.text: Water is essential for all known forms of life. It helps to regulate body temperature and transport nutrients through the bloodstream. Most of the Earth surface is covered by oceans but only a small fraction of that water is fresh and suitable for drinking. Pollution and overuse have led to shortages in many regions. Conservation and better management are needed to ensure that future generations have enough water.
hints: Noun; the planet we live on.

B2.text: Music has been part of human culture for thousands of years. Different societies have developed their own instruments scales and styles of performance. Studies suggest that listening to music can affect mood and even reduce stress. Some researchers believe that music may have helped early humans to bond and cooperate. Today music is used in education therapy and entertainment around the world.

The internet has transformed how people communicate and access information. Email and social media allow instant contact across long distances. However the spread of false information online has become a serious concern. Many countries are debating how to regulate content while protecting free speech. Experts agree that digital literacy is increasingly important for participation in modern society.

Renewable energy sources are becoming more important as the world seeks to reduce carbon emissions. Solar panels and wind turbines can generate electricity without burning fossil fuels. The cost of these technologies has fallen sharply in recent years. Many governments now offer incentives to households and businesses that install renewable systems. Storage solutions are still needed to manage supply when the sun is not shining or the wind is not blowing.

The rise of social media has changed how news is produced and consumed. Anyone with a smartphone can now share updates with a global audience. Traditional journalists argue that professional standards and fact-checking remain essential. Misinformation can spread quickly and some platforms have introduced measures to limit its reach. The relationship between media companies and their audiences continues to evolve.

Biodiversity refers to the variety of life on Earth from genes to entire ecosystems. Human activities such as deforestation and pollution have caused many species to decline. Protected areas and conservation programmes aim to slow or reverse this trend. Scientists warn that losing biodiversity could reduce the resilience of natural systems. International agreements have been established to promote cooperation on this issue.

Artificial intelligence is being used in fields ranging from medicine to finance. Algorithms can analyse large datasets and identify patterns that humans might miss. Concerns have been raised about bias in data and the transparency of automated decisions. Many countries are developing guidelines for the ethical use of AI. The technology is likely to transform industries and job markets in the coming decades.

Global trade has expanded dramatically over the past fifty years. Ships and planes carry goods between continents every day. Trade agreements aim to reduce tariffs and other barriers between countries. Critics point out that benefits are not always shared equally and that some industries suffer from competition. Economists generally agree that open trade has lifted millions out of poverty despite these challenges.

C1.text: Plate tectonics describes the large-scale movement of the Earth lithosphere. The lithosphere is divided into several major plates that float on the underlying asthenosphere. Where plates meet they may diverge converge or slide past one another. These interactions give rise to earthquakes volcanic activity and the formation of mountain ranges. Geologists use this theory to explain the distribution of continents and ocean basins over geological time.

Anthropology examines human societies and cultures in a holistic and comparative way. Ethnographers spend extended periods living among the communities they study in order to understand local perspectives. This method has been criticized for potentially imposing the researcher own framework on the data. Nevertheless detailed fieldwork remains central to the discipline and has produced many influential accounts of social life. Contemporary anthropology also engages with issues of power inequality and globalization.
hints: Adverb; in a way that compares.
Plural noun; researchers who do fieldwork.

C1.text: Astrophysicists use the light from distant objects to infer their composition and motion. Redshift occurs when a source moves away from the observer and its light is stretched toward longer wavelengths. This phenomenon provides evidence that the universe is expanding and has been used to estimate the rate of expansion. Dark matter and dark energy are thought to dominate the total mass and energy content of the universe although they have not been directly observed.
hints: Noun; what something is made of.
Verb: to dominate or make up most of.

C1.text: Linguistic relativity is the idea that the structure of a language affects how its speakers think and perceive the world. Strong versions of this hypothesis have been largely abandoned but weaker versions continue to attract research. For example some studies suggest that grammatical gender can influence the way objects are described. The debate has implications for education translation and the design of international communication systems. Most scholars now favour a moderate position that acknowledges both universal and language-specific effects.
hints: Noun; the way something is built.

C1.text: Cognitive load theory suggests that working memory has a limited capacity and that learning is more effective when instruction is designed to avoid overloading it. Extraneous load is caused by elements that do not support the learning goal such as irrelevant graphics or redundant text. Intrinsic load depends on the complexity of the material itself. Instructional designers aim to reduce extraneous load and to break complex material into manageable segments. The theory has been applied widely in multimedia and online education.

Epigenetics refers to changes in gene expression that do not involve changes to the underlying DNA sequence. Such changes can be influenced by environment diet and stress and some may be passed on to offspring. This has led to renewed interest in how experience can leave a biological legacy across generations. Research in this area has implications for understanding disease development and for public health policy. Critics caution that popular reporting sometimes overstates the extent of epigenetic inheritance.

Philosophy of science examines the assumptions methods and limits of scientific inquiry. One central question is whether scientific theories can be said to approximate the truth or whether they are merely useful tools for prediction. The problem of induction illustrates that generalizing from observed cases to unobserved ones cannot be logically guaranteed. Philosophers disagree about how much this undermines the authority of science. The debate has practical consequences for how evidence is weighted in policy and law.
hints: Plural noun; things taken for granted.

C1.text: Metacognition is the awareness and regulation of one own thinking processes. It includes planning how to approach a task monitoring progress and evaluating outcomes. Students with strong metacognitive skills tend to perform better because they can adjust their strategies when they encounter difficulties. Educators have developed various interventions to foster these skills in the classroom. Research suggests that metacognition can be taught and that it contributes to academic achievement across subjects.

Stellar evolution describes how stars change over their lifetimes from formation to the end of their nuclear burning phase. Low-mass stars may become white dwarfs while high-mass stars can end in supernova explosions and leave behind neutron stars or black holes. The fate of a star depends primarily on its initial mass and composition. Observations across different wavelengths have allowed astronomers to test and refine these models. The study of stellar evolution also informs our understanding of the origin of chemical elements in the universe.
hints: Plural noun; scientists who study stars.

C1.text: Normative ethics is concerned with how people ought to act and what kinds of character they should cultivate. Consequentialist theories judge actions by their outcomes whereas deontological theories focus on duties and rules. Virtue ethics emphasizes the development of good character rather than the application of abstract principles. These frameworks sometimes yield different conclusions when applied to the same practical dilemma. Philosophers continue to debate whether one approach can be unified or whether pluralism is unavoidable.
hints: Adjective; related to what should be.

C1.text: Quantum mechanics challenges our everyday intuition about how matter and energy behave at the smallest scales. Particles can exhibit both wave-like and particle-like properties depending on how they are measured. The uncertainty principle states that certain pairs of quantities cannot be known with arbitrary precision simultaneously. Despite its success in prediction the interpretation of what the theory actually describes remains contested among physicists. Applications of quantum phenomena now underpin technologies such as semiconductors and encryption.

International law governs relations between states and increasingly addresses the conduct of non-state actors. Treaties and customary practice form the primary sources of obligation. Enforcement remains problematic because there is no global police force and states may prioritize national interest over compliance. International courts and tribunals have limited jurisdiction and depend on the consent of states. Debates continue about whether international law is truly law or a form of coordinated morality.

Literary theory offers various frameworks for interpreting texts and for understanding how meaning is produced and received. Structuralist approaches focus on underlying patterns and binary oppositions whereas poststructuralist thought emphasizes instability and the role of the reader. The concept of the author has been questioned and some argue that texts are open to multiple readings. These debates have influenced teaching and research in literature departments worldwide. They also connect to broader questions about knowledge and representation.

Economic models simplify reality in order to isolate key relationships and test hypotheses. Assumptions about rational behaviour and efficient markets have been criticized for failing to predict crises. Behavioural economics has incorporated insights from psychology to explain systematic deviations from rational choice. The field continues to evolve as new data and methods become available. Policy makers often rely on model-based projections despite their known limitations.

The concept of sustainability has shifted from a focus on environmental protection to a broader framework that integrates economic social and ecological dimensions. Critics argue that the term has been diluted through overuse and that measurable standards are needed. Life cycle assessment and similar tools attempt to quantify the impact of products and services. Achieving sustainability at scale will require changes in consumption patterns and in the design of infrastructure. The role of technology and regulation in this transition remains a subject of active debate.

C2.text: The ontological status of mathematical objects has long divided philosophers. Platonists hold that numbers and sets exist in an abstract realm independent of human thought. Nominalists by contrast deny that such entities have any existence beyond their use in language and inference. The dispute has implications for the foundations of science and for the nature of necessity. Contemporary discussions often draw on results from logic and set theory to clarify what commitment to mathematical truth might entail.
hints: Plural noun; believers in abstract objects.

C2.text: Hermeneutics originally concerned the interpretation of sacred texts but has been extended to encompass the understanding of any meaningful human product. The hermeneutic circle describes the process whereby the part and the whole are understood in relation to each other. Gadamer emphasized the role of prejudice and tradition in shaping interpretation and argued that complete objectivity is unattainable. Critics have questioned whether this leads to relativism or whether it merely acknowledges the situated character of understanding. The discipline continues to inform literary theory legal interpretation and the social sciences.

Phenomenology seeks to describe experience as it presents itself without presupposing the existence of an external world or the correctness of scientific explanation. Husserl proposed a method of bracketing whereby the natural attitude is suspended in order to examine the structure of consciousness. The focus is on intentionality the directedness of consciousness toward objects. Later phenomenologists such as Heidegger and Merleau-Ponty emphasized the embodied and situated character of human existence. The tradition has influenced psychiatry aesthetics and the philosophy of mind.

The demarcation problem asks how to distinguish science from pseudoscience and other non-scientific endeavours. Popper proposed falsifiability as a criterion: genuine scientific theories must be capable of being refuted by observation. Critics have pointed out that in practice scientists rarely abandon theories in the face of a single counterexample and that auxiliary assumptions can always be adjusted. The debate intersects with questions about the rationality of theory choice and the role of values in science. No consensus has been reached on a definitive solution.

Consciousness presents perhaps the most intractable problem in contemporary philosophy and cognitive science. There is no agreed account of what it is for a state to be conscious or of how conscious experience relates to physical processes. The hard problem as Chalmers termed it is to explain why and how subjective experience arises at all. Reductive and non-reductive approaches have been proposed but each faces significant objections. The issue has implications for the nature of the self and for ethical questions about the treatment of non-human animals.

Game theory provides a formal framework for analysing strategic interaction among rational agents. The concept of Nash equilibrium identifies outcomes in which no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing strategy. Applications range from economics and political science to biology and computer science. Critics note that the assumption of perfect rationality is often unrealistic and that real agents have limited information and computational capacity. Behavioural game theory has emerged to incorporate these limitations.

The principle of parsimony or Ockham razor holds that among competing explanations the simplest one that fits the data is to be preferred. The justification for this principle has been debated: it may be grounded in epistemic virtue in prior probability or in pragmatic considerations. Critics argue that simplicity is not always a guide to truth and that the principle can be misapplied. The principle has played a role in scientific theory choice and in legal and philosophical reasoning. Its scope and limits remain contested.

Moral particularism rejects the idea that moral judgement can be codified into a set of general principles that apply across all cases. Particularists argue that the morally relevant features of a situation can vary in ways that resist systematic summary. The view has been developed in response to perceived inadequacies in consequentialist and deontological theories. Critics worry that particularism leaves too much to intuition and fails to provide action-guiding content. The debate has implications for moral education and for the possibility of moral expertise.

The problem of other minds arises from the observation that we have direct access only to our own mental states. We infer the mental states of others from their behaviour but this inference is not logically guaranteed. Some philosophers have argued that the problem is illusory and that our grasp of other minds is more direct than traditional epistemology suggests. The issue connects to questions about empathy simulation theory and the nature of social cognition. It also has implications for the philosophy of language and for artificial intelligence.

Epistemic justification concerns the reasons or grounds that make a belief appropriate or warranted. Foundationalists hold that some beliefs are basic and support others in a chain of inference. Coherentists deny that any beliefs are privileged in this way and insist that justification is a matter of fit within a network of beliefs. The Gettier problem showed that the traditional analysis of knowledge as justified true belief is insufficient. Contemporary epistemologists have proposed various alternatives including virtue epistemology and contextualist accounts.

The nature of time has puzzled philosophers and physicists alike. The A-theory holds that the distinction between past present and future is metaphysically fundamental. The B-theory by contrast treats all times as equally real and holds that temporal becoming is an illusion. Relativity theory has complicated the picture by showing that simultaneity is frame-dependent. The debate has implications for free will for the possibility of time travel and for the direction of causation.

Political legitimacy concerns the right of institutions to make binding decisions and the obligation of citizens to comply. Consent theory grounds legitimacy in the agreement of the governed. Critics argue that actual consent is rarely given and that hypothetical or tacit consent does not carry the same normative force. Alternative accounts appeal to fairness to the common good or to the protection of rights. The issue is central to debates about political obligation civil disobedience and the limits of state authority.

Aesthetic experience has been variously characterized as disinterested pleasure as empathy with the object or as a form of cognition. The concept of the aesthetic emerged in the eighteenth century and was linked to the separation of art from craft and utility. Debates persist about whether aesthetic value is objective or subjective and about the relationship between aesthetic and moral value. The arts have been defended both for their intrinsic value and for their contribution to human flourishing. Contemporary aesthetics often engages with mass culture and with the boundaries of art.

The indeterminacy of translation thesis holds that there is no fact of the matter about which of several translations of a language into another is correct. Quine argued that reference is inscrutable and that we cannot uniquely assign meanings to the terms of a theory. The thesis has been taken to support semantic holism and to undermine the notion of determinate meaning. Critics have questioned the argument and its implications for the possibility of radical translation. The debate connects to broader issues in the philosophy of language and mind.

Metaphysical necessity is distinguished from merely contingent truth: what is necessary could not have been otherwise whereas what is contingent could have been different. Kripke argued that some identities including those between names and their bearers are necessary a posteriori. The distinction has been invoked in discussions of essentialism of possible worlds and of the mind-body problem. Critics have questioned whether the modal notions are sufficiently clear and whether they do substantive philosophical work. The concept remains central to contemporary metaphysics.
